components.name: Supabase Auth
components.description: Complete authentication with OAuth, magic links, and email/password. Works seamlessly with Supabase database.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A service that handles user logins and accounts for your app. It manages the 'sign in with Google' button, email/password logins, and remembers who's logged in.
components.plainLanguageWhy: So you don't have to build a login system from scratch. Supabase Auth handles security, password resets, and session management for you.
components.commonUse: User accounts for health apps, student portals, community platforms, civic tools — any app where different people need their own space.
components.skillRequired: Beginner-friendly. Copy a few code snippets, add your Google credentials, and it works. No deep coding knowledge required.

components.name: NextAuth.js
components.description: Authentication for Next.js with 50+ providers. Supports JWT and database sessions.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A login system built specifically for Next.js apps. Supports signing in with Google, GitHub, Twitter, or your own email/password.
components.plainLanguageWhy: If you're building with Next.js and need users to log in, this is the most common choice. It works out of the box with 50+ sign-in options.
components.commonUse: Student logins, community platforms, content tools, civic apps — anywhere you need user accounts quickly.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. You'll need to follow a setup guide but no advanced skills needed. Takes about 20 minutes.

components.name: Clerk
components.description: Drop-in authentication UI with user management, organizations, and MFA built-in.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A complete login system you can drop into any app. It comes with beautiful sign-in screens already designed — you don't have to build any login UI yourself.
components.plainLanguageWhy: The fastest way to get user accounts working. Clerk handles the design, security, and user management dashboard for you.
components.commonUse: School platforms, nonprofit tools, health apps, any project where you need accounts up and running in under 30 minutes.
components.skillRequired: Very beginner-friendly. Paste in a few lines of code and your login screen is live. No design or security knowledge needed.

components.name: Lucia Auth
components.description: Simple, lightweight authentication library. Full control, no vendor lock-in.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A lightweight login library that gives you full control over how authentication works in your app. No third-party services involved.
components.plainLanguageWhy: If you need custom login behavior, care about data privacy, or can't use third-party auth services, Lucia lets you build exactly what you need.
components.commonUse: Privacy-sensitive apps, tools where you control all user data, justice or advocacy platforms with specific compliance needs.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. Requires understanding of how sessions and cookies work. Good documentation but not plug-and-play.

components.name: Stripe
components.description: Industry standard payment processing. Subscriptions, one-time payments, invoicing.
components.plainLanguageWhat: The most widely used payment processing service. It handles credit cards, subscriptions, and marketplace payments securely.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs to charge money — for services, memberships, or products — Stripe is the industry standard and trusted by millions of businesses.
components.commonUse: Sliding-scale services for low-income users, subscription tools, marketplace platforms, donation collection for nonprofits.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. You'll need to understand webhooks (automated notifications) and follow Stripe's setup guide carefully. Worth the effort.

components.name: LemonSqueezy
components.description: Merchant of record. Handles payments, taxes, and compliance for you.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A simpler payment service that also handles taxes and legal compliance in different countries for you.
components.plainLanguageWhy: If you want to accept payments without worrying about international tax laws, LemonSqueezy takes care of that complexity.
components.commonUse: Digital tools and products sold globally, educational resources, software licenses, creator tools.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Simpler than Stripe. Works well for digital products without complex custom checkout needs.

components.name: Paddle
components.description: Complete payments infrastructure. Tax handling and compliance included.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A global payment platform that handles taxes and compliance across 200+ countries automatically.
components.plainLanguageWhy: If your app needs to sell in many countries with different tax rules, Paddle handles all of that automatically.
components.commonUse: Global SaaS tools, digital products sold internationally, subscription services.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. More complex setup than LemonSqueezy but handles more edge cases for global payments.

components.name: OpenAI API
components.description: GPT-4, DALL-E, Whisper, and embeddings. The most widely used AI API.
components.plainLanguageWhat: Access to ChatGPT's intelligence from your own app. You send it a question or task, it responds intelligently — and you control the experience.
components.plainLanguageWhy: To add AI-powered features: answering questions, summarizing documents, translating languages, generating content, or understanding what users write.
components.commonUse: Multilingual health chatbots, document summarizers for legal aid, food resource finders, crisis triage tools, tutoring assistants.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Send text in, get text back. The API is straightforward. The harder part is designing what to ask the AI.

components.name: Anthropic Claude
components.description: Claude API for conversational AI. Strong reasoning and instruction following.
components.plainLanguageWhat: An AI assistant (Claude) that you can talk to from your own app. Known for careful, nuanced responses and following complex instructions.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs AI that reasons carefully, handles sensitive topics well, or needs to follow specific guidelines — Claude is especially strong at this.
components.commonUse: Legal document analysis, healthcare information tools, mental health support assistants, complex document summarization, equity-focused advisory tools.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Same pattern as OpenAI: send a message, get a response. Great documentation and free API tier to start.

components.name: Vercel AI SDK
components.description: Unified SDK for OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and more. Built-in streaming.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A toolkit that makes it easy to add AI chat features to a Next.js app, with responses that stream in word-by-word (like ChatGPT does).
components.plainLanguageWhy: Instead of writing complex AI integration code, this gives you React hooks and components that handle streaming AI responses automatically.
components.commonUse: Chat interfaces, AI assistants, Q&A tools, real-time document summarization — anything where the AI response should appear as it's generated.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. If you're using Next.js, this is the easiest way to add AI chat features. Works with multiple AI providers.

components.name: LangChain.js
components.description: Framework for LLM applications. Chains, agents, RAG, and tools.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A framework for building AI applications that can search through documents, use multiple tools, and perform multi-step reasoning tasks.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your AI app needs to search your own documents, remember context, or chain multiple AI steps together — LangChain is the standard approach.
components.commonUse: Document Q&A systems ('ask questions about this PDF'), policy research tools, multi-step health intake processes, civic data exploration.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. More complex than calling the AI directly. Best if you understand basic JavaScript and have 30–45 minutes to follow the quickstart.

components.name: Pinecone
components.description: Vector database for semantic search, RAG, and recommendations.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A special kind of database that stores information as 'meaning vectors' — so when someone asks a question, it finds the most relevant answers even if the wording is different.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you want your AI to search through a large collection of documents and find the most relevant one — not just keyword matching, but actual meaning matching.
components.commonUse: Search through grant databases, legal aid resources, health guidelines, food assistance programs — 'find me grants for youth housing in California.'
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. You need to understand the concept of embeddings (turning text into numbers that represent meaning). Good tutorials available.

components.name: Replicate
components.description: Run open-source ML models in the cloud. Stable Diffusion, Llama, and more.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A service that lets you run powerful AI models (image generation, language models, audio tools) without needing a powerful computer.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you need to generate images, run specialized AI models, or use AI tools that aren't available through OpenAI — Replicate hosts thousands of open-source models.
components.commonUse: Generating visual aids for educational tools, food identification from photos, health symptom image analysis, accessibility tools like image captioning.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Simple API: send an input (image, text), get an output back. The model browser makes it easy to find what you need.

components.name: Hugging Face
components.description: Hub for ML models. Inference API and Transformers.js for browser.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A platform with thousands of free, open-source AI models for text, images, audio, and more — many specialized for languages other than English.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you need AI that runs without sending data to a third-party company, or when you need specialized models (like translation for a minority language, or medical text analysis).
components.commonUse: Multilingual health tools, offline-capable community apps, food classification from photos, environmental monitoring analysis.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. More setup than OpenAI/Claude but much more flexibility. Good for teams with someone who understands Python or ML basics.

components.name: Supabase
components.description: Postgres + Auth + Realtime + Storage. The all-in-one backend.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A complete backend service — like a smart filing cabinet + login system + file storage all in one. It stores all your app's data securely and lets you access it from anywhere.
components.plainLanguageWhy: Instead of setting up a server, database, and auth system separately, Supabase gives you everything in one place for free to start.
components.commonUse: Community health records, student progress tracking, neighborhood resource maps, emergency contact systems, food pantry inventory, case management tools.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. The visual dashboard makes it easy to create tables and manage data without writing code. SQL knowledge is helpful but not required.

components.name: PlanetScale
components.description: Serverless MySQL with branching. Scale infinitely.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A database that scales automatically and lets you make schema changes safely — like having a test copy of your database before applying changes to the real one.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you need a reliable, scalable database that handles growth automatically and lets you safely experiment with changes.
components.commonUse: Civic platforms expecting large user bases, education tools that need to scale, economic data tools.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Similar to Supabase but MySQL-based. Good if your team already knows MySQL.

components.name: Neon
components.description: Serverless Postgres with branching and autoscaling.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A Postgres database that scales to zero when not in use (saving money) and scales up automatically when people use your app.
components.plainLanguageWhy: A great free alternative to Supabase for just the database layer. Ideal if you're using a separate auth system but need solid Postgres storage.
components.commonUse: Community tools, education platforms, health apps — any project that needs a reliable free-tier database.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Quick setup, free tier, good documentation. Works well with Prisma or Drizzle for easier data management.

components.name: Turso
components.description: Edge SQLite database. Replicate globally, query locally.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A database that runs at the 'edge' — meaning it stores copies of your data close to users all around the world, so your app feels fast everywhere.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs to work fast globally, or even partially offline — Turso replicates data close to wherever your users are.
components.commonUse: Disaster response apps that need to work in low-connectivity areas, food supply tracking across regions, field health worker tools.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Simple SQLite-based. Good for teams building apps that need to work offline or in areas with poor internet.

components.name: Prisma
components.description: Type-safe ORM. Auto-generated types, migrations, and studio.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A tool that makes working with databases much easier from TypeScript/JavaScript. It lets you interact with your database using code instead of SQL queries.
components.plainLanguageWhy: Instead of writing database queries by hand, Prisma auto-generates safe, typed functions so your code knows exactly what shape the data is.
components.commonUse: Any project using a database where the team wants type safety and easy migrations — health records, education platforms, civic tools.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Prisma Studio (a visual database browser) makes it easy to explore data without SQL. The schema file is readable even without coding experience.

components.name: Drizzle ORM
components.description: Lightweight TypeScript ORM. SQL-like syntax, zero dependencies.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A lightweight database toolkit for TypeScript. It writes SQL queries in a way that looks like regular code, so it's easier to read and less error-prone.
components.plainLanguageWhy: A leaner alternative to Prisma. If you like writing SQL but want TypeScript safety on top, Drizzle is minimal and fast.
components.commonUse: Civic data tools, economic reporting platforms, lightweight community apps where you want precise database control.
components.skillRequired: Beginner to intermediate. Helpful if you understand basic SQL. The syntax is intuitive and well-documented.

components.name: Upstash Redis
components.description: Serverless Redis. Caching, rate limiting, and queues.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A fast, temporary data store — like a super-fast whiteboard that stores short-term information your app needs to access instantly.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs to respond quickly to many users at once, or needs to store short-lived data like session tokens, rate limits, or live counts.
components.commonUse: Crisis dashboards showing live counts, health tools managing high traffic, real-time resource availability boards, abuse prevention.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Simple key-value API. Takes about 10 minutes to set up. Free tier is generous for most hackathon projects.

components.name: shadcn/ui
components.description: Beautiful components. Copy-paste, not npm install. You own the code.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A collection of beautiful, pre-built interface components — buttons, forms, dialogs, tables — that you copy into your project and customize.
components.plainLanguageWhy: Instead of designing every button and form from scratch, shadcn gives you polished, accessible components that look professional immediately.
components.commonUse: Dashboards for health workers, community portals, civic data tools, resource directories — any app that needs a clean, professional UI quickly.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. The component examples are clearly documented. You copy the code, paste it in, and style it with Tailwind. No deep design skills needed.

components.name: Radix UI
components.description: Unstyled, accessible primitives. Build your own design system.
components.plainLanguageWhat: The building blocks underneath shadcn/ui. Provides accessible dropdowns, dialogs, tooltips, and more — without any styling, so you design them yourself.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you need full design control but still want accessibility built in. Radix handles keyboard navigation and screen reader support automatically.
components.commonUse: Accessibility-focused civic tools, health apps that need to serve users with disabilities, custom design systems for government-adjacent platforms.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. You'll need CSS/Tailwind knowledge to style these components. Best for teams with a designer or strong frontend developer.

components.name: Tremor
components.description: Dashboard components. Charts, KPIs, and tables for React.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A set of pre-built dashboard components — charts, stat cards, tables, and filters — that let you build a data dashboard quickly.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs to show data visually to users — counts, trends, comparisons — Tremor gives you professional-looking charts without building them from scratch.
components.commonUse: Community health dashboards, environmental monitoring displays, food security reporting, civic open data visualization, energy usage tracking.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Component props are intuitive. Pass your data in, get a chart out. Works well without deep charting knowledge.

components.name: Recharts
components.description: Composable charting library built on D3.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A charting library that lets you create bar charts, line graphs, pie charts, and more with React components.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs to visualize data — trends over time, comparisons between groups, geographic distributions — Recharts makes it easy to build interactive charts.
components.commonUse: Climate data visualization, health outcome tracking, economic inequality charts, food access mapping, energy usage graphs.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Lots of examples to copy from. You'll need to understand your data structure to pass it in correctly, but the API is approachable.

components.name: Framer Motion
components.description: Production-ready animations. Gestures, layout animations, and more.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A library that adds smooth animations and motion to your app — things sliding in, fading out, or reacting to user gestures.
components.plainLanguageWhy: Animations make your app feel polished and alive. Framer Motion makes adding them easy without needing CSS animation expertise.
components.commonUse: Educational tools that guide users step by step, health apps with calming transitions, civic platforms that need to feel trustworthy and polished.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Wrap your component in a `motion.div`, add animation props, and it just works. Excellent documentation.

components.name: React Hook Form
components.description: Performant forms. Minimal re-renders, easy validation.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A library for building forms — registration forms, intake forms, survey forms — that validates user input and handles submission cleanly.
components.plainLanguageWhy: Forms are everywhere in social-impact apps: health intake, resource requests, civic feedback. React Hook Form makes them fast to build and reliable.
components.commonUse: Health intake forms, shelter registration, grant applications, civic feedback tools, food assistance enrollment, legal aid intake.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Works by adding hooks to your form inputs. Pairs well with Zod for validation. Clear documentation.

components.name: Zod
components.description: TypeScript-first schema validation. Works great with React Hook Form.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A validation library that checks if data (from forms, APIs, or users) is the right shape and type before you use it.
components.plainLanguageWhy: To catch bad data before it causes problems. Especially important in health, legal, or crisis apps where incorrect data can have real consequences.
components.commonUse: Validating health intake forms, checking API responses, ensuring civic data submissions are complete, validating grant application fields.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Define what your data should look like, and Zod checks it. Very readable syntax. Pairs naturally with React Hook Form.

components.name: TanStack Table
components.description: Headless table library. Sorting, filtering, pagination.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A powerful table component that can handle large amounts of data with sorting, filtering, and pagination built in.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs to display a lot of rows of data that users need to sort and filter — like a list of resources, people, cases, or records.
components.commonUse: Resource directories, patient or client lists, open data civic tools, food pantry inventories, grant tracking systems.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. More setup than basic tables but very powerful. Good documentation and examples to copy from.

components.name: cmdk
components.description: Command palette component. Fast, accessible, composable.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A searchable command menu (like pressing Cmd+K in many apps) that lets users quickly find and navigate to anything in your app.
components.plainLanguageWhy: Makes your app feel powerful and keyboard-accessible. Users can search across all features without clicking through menus.
components.commonUse: Resource search tools, civic data explorers, health service finders, educational content navigation.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Drop it in, define your commands, and it works. shadcn/ui includes a version that's even easier to add.

components.name: Resend
components.description: Email API for developers. Simple, fast, reliable.
components.plainLanguageWhat: An email sending service for your app. When your app needs to send emails — confirmations, notifications, alerts — Resend delivers them reliably.
components.plainLanguageWhy: Email is essential for most apps: confirming signups, sending resource alerts, notifying users. Resend makes sending transactional emails simple.
components.commonUse: Appointment reminders for health apps, shelter availability alerts, educational progress updates, crisis notifications, housing application status.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Send an email in 5 lines of code. Great documentation and generous free tier.

components.name: React Email
components.description: Build emails with React components. Preview and test locally.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A tool for designing email templates using React components, so your automated emails look beautiful and work across all email clients.
components.plainLanguageWhy: HTML emails are notoriously hard to style. React Email gives you components that render correctly in Gmail, Outlook, and Apple Mail.
components.commonUse: Welcome emails for community platforms, health appointment reminders, civic update newsletters, educational progress reports.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. If you know React, writing email templates feels natural. Preview server lets you see how emails look before sending.

components.name: Twilio
components.description: SMS, voice, and video APIs. Global reach.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A service that lets your app send text messages, make phone calls, or run video chats — to any phone number in the world.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your users may not have smartphones or internet access but do have a basic phone — SMS reaches everyone. Critical for crisis and health tools.
components.commonUse: Health appointment reminders by SMS, emergency alerts, food pantry availability texts, legal aid notification, shelter bed availability.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. You'll need a Twilio account with a phone number and understanding of webhooks. Worth it for apps targeting non-smartphone users.

components.name: Uploadthing
components.description: File uploads for Next.js. Type-safe, fast, free tier.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A service that handles file uploads in Next.js apps — letting users upload photos, documents, or other files securely.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs users to submit documents — health records, IDs, legal forms, school assignments — Uploadthing handles the storage and security.
components.commonUse: Health document uploads, legal aid form submissions, housing application documents, educational assignment submissions.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Purpose-built for Next.js. Good documentation and type-safe file handling. Free tier handles most hackathon use cases.

components.name: Cloudinary
components.description: Image and video management. Transformations, optimization, CDN.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A service that stores, optimizes, and delivers images and videos for your app. It automatically resizes and compresses media for fast loading.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app handles lots of photos or videos — health images, educational media, food photos — Cloudinary serves them fast and optimized automatically.
components.commonUse: Food identification photos, health visual aids, educational video libraries, civic documentation photos, arts platforms.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Upload an image, get a URL back with automatic optimization. Free tier is generous. Good SDK documentation.

components.name: Inngest
components.description: Background jobs and workflows. Event-driven, durable execution.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A service that runs tasks in the background — things your app needs to do that might take time, like sending a batch of notifications or processing uploaded files.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you need to do something that takes longer than a web request — like sending 500 emails, processing data overnight, or retrying failed tasks automatically.
components.commonUse: Batch health alerts, nightly food inventory updates, automated follow-up sequences, civic data processing pipelines.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. Requires understanding of event-driven patterns. Great debugging tools and good documentation for hackathon use.

components.name: Trigger.dev
components.description: Background jobs with observability. Cron, webhooks, and long-running tasks.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A tool for running scheduled and background tasks — things that happen on a timer or in response to events, with a clear view of what's running.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you need scheduled jobs (run every night at midnight) or long-running tasks with visibility into what's happening and easy debugging.
components.commonUse: Daily environmental data pulls, weekly food pantry stock reports, scheduled health check-ins, automated civic data refreshes.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. Similar to Inngest. Trigger.dev has strong observability — you can see every job run and what happened. Good for debugging during hackathons.

components.name: Pusher
components.description: Realtime infrastructure. Channels, presence, and webhooks.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A service that makes your app update in real-time — so when something changes on the server, all users instantly see the update without refreshing.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs live updates: a crisis dashboard showing current counts, a live food availability board, or a collaborative tool where changes appear instantly.
components.commonUse: Live crisis situation dashboards, real-time food pantry availability, live voting or polling tools, collaborative civic planning tools.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Simpler than Socket.io. Good for most real-time use cases without needing deep WebSocket knowledge.

components.name: Socket.io
components.description: Realtime bidirectional communication. Works everywhere.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A library for real-time two-way communication between your app and its users — like a live chat system or collaborative editing tool.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When users need to communicate in real-time or when the server needs to push urgent updates — Socket.io handles this reliably with fallbacks for poor connections.
components.commonUse: Crisis communication tools, live Q&A for civic events, real-time collaborative health intake, emergency coordination apps.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. Requires Node.js server setup. More control than Pusher but more complex. Worth it for apps needing custom real-time behavior.

components.name: Liveblocks
components.description: Collaboration infrastructure. Presence, cursors, and conflict-free data.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A service that adds real-time collaboration to your app — multiple users can edit the same document or canvas at the same time, like Google Docs.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs multiple people working on the same thing simultaneously — a shared planning canvas, collaborative resource map, or group document.
components.commonUse: Collaborative community planning tools, shared resource maps, educational collaborative tools, civic budget planning interfaces.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. Requires understanding of real-time sync concepts. Good documentation and React hooks make it more accessible.

components.name: Excalidraw
components.description: Virtual whiteboard. Hand-drawn feel, real-time collaboration.
components.plainLanguageWhat: An embeddable virtual whiteboard with a hand-drawn feel. Users can draw, diagram, and collaborate in real-time without leaving your app.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs a whiteboard for brainstorming, diagramming, or visual collaboration — Excalidraw embeds in minutes and looks great.
components.commonUse: Community planning tools, educational collaborative sessions, health system mapping, civic process diagramming.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Embed with a few lines of code. Real-time collaboration works out of the box. Very well-documented.

components.name: tldraw
components.description: Infinite canvas. Drawing, shapes, and real-time sync.
components.plainLanguageWhat: An infinite canvas for drawing, diagramming, and collaborating visually. More flexible than Excalidraw with a cleaner feel.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you need an embeddable canvas for visual work — mapping systems, drawing workflows, creative collaboration.
components.commonUse: System mapping for civic tools, educational visual exercises, health journey mapping, participatory design tools.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Embed and customize with React. Good for non-technical team members once it's set up.

components.name: Monaco Editor
components.description: VS Code's editor as a component. Syntax highlighting, intellisense.
components.plainLanguageWhat: The same code editor that powers VS Code, embedded in your app. Supports syntax highlighting and autocomplete for dozens of programming languages.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When your app needs users to write or edit code, queries, or configuration — Monaco gives them a professional coding experience inside your tool.
components.commonUse: Coding education platforms, civic data query builders, policy text editors, technical training tools.
components.skillRequired: Intermediate. More setup than Sandpack but more powerful for pure editing use cases. Worth it for coding education tools.

components.name: Sandpack
components.description: Live code editor and preview. In-browser bundling.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A live coding environment you can embed in your app — users write code and see the result instantly, without leaving the page.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When you're building an educational or coding tool and want users to experiment with code and see results live — Sandpack handles all the complexity.
components.commonUse: Coding bootcamp platforms, tech education for underserved communities, interactive programming tutorials, code challenge platforms.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Embed with a few props. Much easier than Monaco for full live-preview use cases. Built by the CodeSandbox team.

components.name: Zustand
components.description: Simple state management. Tiny, fast, scalable.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A simple way to manage shared state in your React app — like keeping track of which user is logged in, what's in a cart, or what filters are active across many components.
components.plainLanguageWhy: When multiple parts of your app need to share information (like a user's selections or current status), Zustand keeps it organized without complex setup.
components.commonUse: Tracking session state in health or crisis apps, managing filter state in civic data tools, storing user preferences across pages.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. One of the simplest state management solutions in React. Minimal boilerplate and great documentation.

components.name: TanStack Query
components.description: Async state management. Caching, refetching, and more.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A tool that manages fetching data from your API or database — handling loading states, caching results, and automatically refreshing stale data.
components.plainLanguageWhy: Instead of manually tracking whether data is loading, cached, or outdated, TanStack Query handles all of that. Your components just ask for data and get it.
components.commonUse: Live resource availability tools, health data dashboards that auto-refresh, food availability apps, civic data explorers with real-time updates.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Well-documented hooks-based API. The DevTools panel makes debugging data fetching very transparent during a hackathon.

components.name: Posthog
components.description: Product analytics. Session replay, feature flags, A/B tests.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A tool that shows you how users actually use your app — which features they click, where they drop off, and session recordings of real interactions.
components.plainLanguageWhy: After launch, you need to understand if your app is actually solving the problem. Posthog shows you user behavior so you can improve the right things.
components.commonUse: Understanding if health app users find the right resources, seeing where civic tool users get confused, tracking feature adoption for educational platforms.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Add a script tag or install the SDK and you're tracking events. Open-source and self-hostable for privacy-sensitive apps.

components.name: Sentry
components.description: Error tracking and performance monitoring.
components.plainLanguageWhat: A monitoring service that catches errors in your app in real-time and tells you exactly what went wrong, on which device, and for which user.
components.plainLanguageWhy: After launch, bugs will happen. Sentry notifies you immediately when something breaks so you can fix it fast — especially important for health or crisis apps.
components.commonUse: Any app where reliability matters: health tools, crisis platforms, civic infrastructure, legal aid tools — you need to know the moment something fails.
components.skillRequired: Beginner. Install the SDK, wrap your app, and errors are automatically captured and reported. Dashboard is clear and actionable.
